Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the skate park, phone pressed to my ear, headset crackling with the voices of my fellow controllers. My stepbrother, Jamie, was tightening his helmet, eyes fixed on the steep, uneven ramp. He grinned at me, “Watch this!” My heart pounded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But my other ear was tuned to the urgent chatter from the tower—an aircraft was about to cross into the neighboring sector, and I needed to coordinate the handoff smoothly. 

“Sector Bravo, confirm handoff for Flight 218,” I said, trying to keep my voice steady. Jamie’s skateboard clattered as he positioned himself at the top of the ramp. I wanted to shout at him to stop, to wait until I could give him my full attention, but the expectation at work was clear: no distractions, no mistakes. My hands shook as I tried to split my focus, torn between the safety of hundreds of passengers in the sky and the safety of my brother on the ground. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose.
